I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $50,000,000 in Clifford Capital Holdings Pte. Ltd. (CCH) for the Asian 
Sustainable  Infrastructure  Mobilization  Project. 1  The  report  also  describes  the  proposed 
administration of an equity investment of up to $45,000,000 to be provided by the Leading Asia’s 
Private Infrastructure Fund (LEAP), and if the Board approves the proposed equity investment, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the equity 
investment. 2 
 
2.  CCH is raising equity capital from new and existing shareholders to be drawn from 2020 
to 2024 to scale up its investments in sustainable infrastructure through the expansion of two 
existing  group  companies—Clifford  Capital  Pte.  Ltd.  (CCPL)  and  Pierfront  Capital  Fund 
Management Pte. Ltd. (Pierfront)—and the establishment of two new group companies—Bayfront 
Infrastructure Management Pte. Ltd. (BIM) and a supply chain financing (SCF) entity.3 The equity 
investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of up to $95 million will secure a board seat for 
ADB at CCH. 4 CCH’s other existing shareholders include Temasek, Standard Chartered Bank, 
DBS Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC), Prudential Assurance Company 
Singapore (Pte) Limited, and John Hancock.5 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Developing Asia will require annual infrastructure investments of $1.7 trillion to 2030 to 
sustain economic growth and effectively combat climate change.6 Presently, 70% of infrastructure 
investment in Asia is financed by the public sector, which is unsustainable if developing Asia's 
infrastructure financing needs are to be met.7 Moreover, as governments are allocating public 
funds for emergency response and relief efforts related to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic, there will be a greater reliance on private sector funding to close the infrastructure gap 
in  developing  Asia.  In  the  private  sector  in  Asia,  infrastructure  financing  is  dominated  by 
commercial banks, export credit agencies, infrastructure funds, pension funds, and development 
finance institutions (DFIs). However, the implementation of Basel III, with its stricter capital 
adequacy requirements, will limit the lending capacity of commercial banks, thus increasing the 
challenge of obtaining long-term financing for infrastructure projects. The rise of funds focused on 
providing debt and equity for infrastructure assets, as well as increasing financial innovation 
through securitization, can help to address some of these financing needs. CCH, through its four 
complementary  group  companies  and  their  origination  and  distribution  platforms,  provides 
commercial financing for infrastructure and real assets, which is expected to catalyze and attract 
long-term institutional capital to this underserved market segment in Asia. 
 
 
1  “Sustainable infrastructure” is defined as infrastructure that is designed, built, and operated to be durable, in ways 
that are socially inclusive and economically viable, while protecting the environment. 
2  Financing partner: Japan International Cooperation Agency. 
3  The organizational chart is in Ownership, Management, and Governance (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). Note that BIM is operational as of 2 April 2020. 
4  Out of the proposed equity investment of up to $95 million, $50 million will be funded by ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources and $45 million will be funded by LEAP. 
5  Existing CCPL shareholders swapped their shareholdings into CCH and together with Temasek’s indirect wholly 
owned subsidiary, Aranda Investments Pte. Ltd., executed a first close on 26 March 2020. 
6  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2017. Public Financing of Infrastructure in Asia: In Search of New Solutions. Manila.

2 
4.  ADB has existing relationships with the senior management and board of directors of 
CCH’s key subsidiary, CCPL, from prior engagements in Asia’s infrastructure market. In 2015, 
ADB entered into its first cofinancing with CCPL through the Myingyan Natural Gas Power Project 
in Myanmar.8 ADB provided a political risk guarantee and a B loan participation for commercial 
lenders (including CCPL) to mobilize long-term, private capital into Myanmar’s first private sector 
independent power producer (IPP). 
 
5.  CCPL  was  established  with  support  from  the  Government  of  Singapore  to  provide 
commercially-driven  project  finance  and  structured  finance  solutions  to  Singapore-based 
companies that invest equity in, or provide services or equipment to, infrastructure, offshore 
marine, and shipping assets globally.9 Since its inception in 2012, CCPL has grown its loan 
portfolio to $1.9 billion as of September 2019. In 2016, CCPL supported the establishment of 
Pierfront  Capital,  a  private  credit  fund  manager,  which  provides  mezzanine  financing  for 
infrastructure  and  real  assets.  In  2018,  CCPL,  through  Bayfront  Infrastructure  Capital, 
successfully closed a $458 million inaugural securitization of project and infrastructure finance 
loans from Asia, drawing institutional capital from 16 investors globally. In March 2020, existing 
CCPL shareholders have swapped their shareholding in CCPL for new shares in CCH. CCH is 
raising additional capital from new, strategic investors to fund its future growth plans. ADB’s 
investment will support CCH’s growth in sustainable infrastructure financing in developing Asia. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
6.  CCH is a private holding company established in Singapore. CCH owns the following 
group companies registered in Singapore: 
(i)  Clifford Capital Pte. Ltd. CCPL is a lead arranger and provider of project and 
structured finance to qualifying greenfield and brownfield infrastructure assets 
globally.10 [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] Some of the portfolio 
highlights include the Greenko bond issuance (India) in 2016 and 2017, Myingyan 
IPP (Myanmar) in 2017, and Sirajganj IPP (Bangladesh) in 2016. The Government 
of Singapore, rated AAA by Standard and Poor’s and Fitch, guarantees all CCPL’s 
debt of up to $3.5 billion, providing CCPL access to competitive long-term funding. 
(ii)  Bayfront Infrastructure Management Pte. Ltd. BIM will invest in brownfield 
infrastructure assets, acquiring and warehousing primarily dollar-denominated 
infrastructure  loans  from  commercial  banks. 11  It  will  securitize  the  loans, 
transferring its exposure to institutional investors (such as insurance companies 
and pension funds) through exchange-listed securitized note issuances.12 BIM’s 
warehousing facility benefits from a Government of Singapore funding guarantee 
of up to $1.8 billion, which allows BIM to hold loans longer prior to securitization, 
and  through  periods  of  market  dislocation.  [CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION 
DELETED]  
(iii)  Pierfront Capital Fund Management Pte. Ltd. Pierfront’s Fund I was launched 
in 2016 with $220 million from two existing CCPL shareholders, Temasek and 
SMBC.  Pierfront  leveraged  CCPL’s  existing  sector  knowledge,  network,  and

7.  Innovative features. As one of the region’s leading infrastructure financing platforms with 
holistic origination and distribution capabilities, CCH provides innovative financing solutions 
across the entire capital structure (senior debt, mezzanine financing, loan securitization, and 
working  capital  financing)  of  infrastructure  and  real  assets.  With  strong  backing  from  the 
Government of Singapore and strategic investors including ADB, CCH is well-positioned to 
leverage the capital, innovation, knowledge, and partnerships from Singapore’s infrastructure 
ecosystem to address Asia’s infrastructure gap, which has been further widened by the COVID-
19 crisis, and  contribute to the post-COVID-19 rebuilding efforts. 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
8.  Ownership. Temasek will be CCH’s anchor investor. Temasek has a net portfolio value 
of S$306 billion (as at 31 March 2020) and overall corporate credit ratings of Aaa/AAA by Moody’s 
Investors Service and S&P Global Ratings respectively. The existing CCPL shareholders, DBS 
Bank,  John  Hancock,  Prudential  Assurance  Company  Singapore  (Pte)  Limited,  Standard 
Chartered Bank, and SMBC, together with Temasek, have consolidated their shareholding into 
CCH as of March 2020. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
9.  ADB conducted integrity due diligence.13 CCH’s founder shareholders, managers, and 
significant contracting entities do not appear to constitute a significant or potentially significant 
integrity  risk,  as  there  is  no  unresolved  or  substantiated  adverse  media  or  other  relevant 
information related to them. Tax integrity due diligence was not required. 
 
10.  Management. CCH will have management oversight over all group companies, with 
centralized support functions. In addition to their core origination and front office functions, each 
operating company will have its own risk management team, which will report on a matrix basis 
to the respective operating company head(s) and the group chief risk officer (who will also be 
supported by a group risk team). Each operating company will have its own board of directors 
and credit committee. All other committees (group risk committee; governance, nomination, and 
compensation committee; and audit and finance committee) will be centralized at the CCH level.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
17.  ADB’s assistance will have two components: (i) an equity investment in CCH of up to $50 
million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources; and (ii) a parallel equity investment in CCH of up 
to  $45  million  from  LEAP,  to  be  administered  by  ADB  (footnote  2).    [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will monitor the project throughout its duration. CCH will provide ADB with financial 
reports at predetermined regular intervals, including (i) annual audited financial statements, (ii) 
quarterly reports to its board and shareholders, (iii) annual reports on selected development 
effectiveness (including gender) indicators, and (iv) annual reporting on environmental and social 
performance. For significant environmental and social events relating to underlying assets, CCH 
undertakes to report to ADB promptly. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
19.  Support sustainable and inclusive growth as a strategic shareholder. ADB will be 
CCH’s first multilateral investor and will provide patient capital for CCH’s growth. As a Board 
member, ADB will provide strategic inputs into CCH’s business plan(s) to drive CCH’s operations 
towards more inclusive and sustainable infrastructure development in ADB’s developing member 
countries  (DMCs).  ADB’s  strong  network  of  clients,  government  relationships,  technical 
assistance and project preparation capabilities, as well as cofinancing partners will help CCH 
substantially increase its share of sustainable infrastructure assets in ADB’s DMCs through 
identifying, structuring, financing, and implementing bankable projects. In addition, while ADB’s 
equity capital will directly contribute towards increasing CCH’s ability to leverage and mobilize 
private investments in frontier markets and emerging sectors, it will also indirectly contribute, 
through the multiplier effect, towards job creation and ADB’s climate targets in its DMCs. 
 
20.  Enhance  mobilization  through  cofinancing  opportunities.  As  long-term  private 
funding for infrastructure is becoming even more constrained during the COVID-19 crisis in Asia, 
ADB’s anchor investment is needed not only to build CCH’s long-term capital base but also to 
boost investor confidence and mobilizations amid market dislocations. CCH will gain unparalleled 
access to potential cofinancing and co-investment opportunities with ADB. [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] By cofinancing alongside ADB in emerging countries (Group A or B 
countries) and sectors (such as renewable energy and environmental infrastructure), CCH can 
develop newfound market or sector expertise and invest on its own or mobilize other private 
investors  in  the  future.14 Further,  through  ADB’s  resident  missions,  including  the  newly 
 
14 ADB. 2019. Operations Manual: Classification and Graduation of Developing Member Countries. OM A1. Manila.

established Singapore office, ADB can offer a platform to CCH to propel sustainable infrastructure 
development in Asia through enhanced knowledge, cofinancing, and partnerships. 
 
21.  Strengthen environmental and social safeguards and capacity building. Through its 
investment in CCH, there will be an opportunity for ADB to (i) introduce improvements to the 
existing environmental and social management systems (ESMS) adopted or to be implemented 
by its group companies and (ii) strengthen the capacity and expertise of CCH and its group 
companies in managing its environmental and social risks in accordance with international best 
practices.15 
 
22.  Improve gender inclusivity at Clifford Capital Holdings Pte. Ltd. According to the 
McKinsey Global Institute, women are often over-represented in junior positions and under-
represented in leadership and management positions in the finance and insurance subsectors in 
Singapore.16 Through ADB’s investment, CCH will enhance gender inclusivity through greater 
representation of women in management and decision-making roles at CCH.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
28.  The project is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal 8.10 as it will strengthen the 
capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance, 
and financial services for all.17 The project will have the following  outcome: private sector 
financing for sustainable infrastructure projects in ADB’s DMCs increased.18 
 
29.  The project has the following outputs: (i) CCH’s capital base is expanded; (ii) up to $95 
million of ADB equity capital raised and sustainably invested in low-carbon infrastructure projects 
in ADB’s DMCs, and partly in Group A or B countries; and (iii) gender inclusivity at CCH improved. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
30.  In line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, this project supports ADB’s focus on mobilizing and 
catalyzing financial resources for development and expanding ADB’s private sector operations to

support  ADB’s  seven  operational  priorities. 19 In  line  with  the  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department’s 2019 operational plan, the project also supports increased parallel cofinancing and 
co-investment  opportunities  in  ADB’s  priority  sectors  including  environmental  infrastructure, 
transport,  and  information  and  communication  technology.20 This  is  also  aligned  with  the 
respective country partnership strategies, as many of ADB’s DMCs emphasize the need for 
private sector investment and growth. Through a collaborative One ADB approach involving 
ADB’s regional departments, Office of Public–Private Partnership, and Sustainable Development 
and  Climate  Change  Department,  ADB  aims  to  accelerate  and  increase  private  sector 
investments in many of its frontier markets and sectors. 
 
31.  This  regional  project  strongly  supports  operational  priority  7  (fostering  regional 
cooperation and integration), as it expands global and regional investment opportunities in 
infrastructure in Asia. The establishment of CCH is part of the Government of Singapore’s regional 
initiative to support Asia’s social and economic growth through infrastructure development, with 
Singapore as the regional infrastructure development hub. CCPL’s current portfolio comprises 
several cross-border infrastructure projects, exemplifying regional cooperation among financiers, 
borrowers, and sponsors located across multiple countries in Asia. This project aligns with other 
regional ADB initiatives such as the partnership between Infrastructure Asia and ADB to promote 
innovative and green financing for sustainable infrastructure in Southeast Asia.21 Through CCH’s 
current  investments  in  ports,  shipping,  transport,  and  information  and  communications 
technology, this project also promotes higher-quality connectivity and integration within Asia. 
 
32.  The project supports operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities) as it aims to increase private investments in some of the poorest and most vulnerable 
ADB DMCs. The lack of capital flows, especially private sector financing, into such countries slows 
poverty alleviation and economic growth. Through ADB’s investment, CCH will commit to making 
at least two additional investments in Group A or B countries, thereby bringing private sector 
financing and opportunities to the most vulnerable countries and communities. 
 
33.  The project supports operational priority 3 (tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability)  as  CCH  aims  to  expand 
investments in renewables. In line with the Government of Singapore’s strategy of becoming a 
pioneer  in  green  financing,  Singapore's  central  bank  has  announced  a  $2  billion  green 
investments program to drive growth in sustainable finance, which CCH will be able to support.22 
The project will contribute to ADB’s climate financing target of $80 billion cumulatively from 2019 
to 2030; $30 million of ADB’s own resources will finance climate mitigation investments. 23 
 
34.  This project also promotes ADB’s operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender 
equality) by enhancing women’s participation and access to decision-making and leadership roles 
within CCH. CCH will commit to offering professional skills and leadership training to its female 
staff and increasing the representation of women in management and decision-making roles.

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
35.  The investment is classified category A for impacts on the environment, involuntary 
resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples.24 ADB  has  assessed  the  environmental  and  social  
impacts and risks associated with CCH and its group companies’ existing and future portfolio, and 
their commitment and capacity for environmental and social management. [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] The enhanced ESMS will set out requirements, as applicable, for 
compliance with national labor laws and measures to comply with the internationally recognized 
core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001). The enhanced ESMS 
will also contain requirements, as applicable, for information disclosure and consultation with 
affected people in accordance with ADB requirements. ADB will require annual reports from CCH 
that include (i) the nature of operating company investment activities and categorization, (ii) 
compliance with safeguard and social requirements, (iii) compliance with applicable national and 
international laws and standards, and (iv) evidence that ADB’s proceeds were used to fund ADB 
eligible investments. 
 
36.  Some gender elements. The project is categorized as having some gender elements. 
CCH commits to implement measures to promote gender equality in its business activities 
following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998). CCH will ensure adequate female 
representation  in  management  and  decision-making  roles  at  CCH.  [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
37.  CCH was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
38.  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
39.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),25 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the governments of the 
ADB member countries in which projects financed by CCH through CCPL and enabled by the 
ADB financing are located have no objection to the proposed assistance to CCH. ADB will enter 
into  suitable  finance  documentation,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  following 
approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the

metadata.Subject:
Clifford Capital Holdings Pte. Ltd. (CCH) is raising equity capital from new and existing shareholders to be drawn from 2020 to 2024 to scale up its investments in sustainable infrastructure through the expansion of two existing group companies—Clifford Capital Pte. Ltd. (CCPL) and Pierfront Capital Fund Management Pte. Ltd. (Pierfront)—and the establishment of two new group companies—Bayfront Infrastructure Management Pte. Ltd. (BIM) and a supply chain financing (SCF) entity.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated July 2020 is provided for the ADB regional project 53397-001.
